tit.cmt: すぐ下に説明があるためここはタイトルのみとしました。

sen.j: 保長（ほちょう）とは、古代日本の律令制で設置された五保の長。
sen.e: A hocho was a headman of goho (the end administrative organization obliged to prevent crime and pay tax jointly) established under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code [historical law system]) in the ancient Japan.

sen.j: 戸令によれば、5つの戸をによる五保（保）を編成させて、犯罪や逃亡の防止などのための相互監視などを行わせ、保長はその責任者となった。
sen.e: According to the Code of Households, goho (ho) consisted of five households and performed mutual surveillance to prevent crime and escape, and hocho was in charge of the goho.

sen.j: 当初は地方の農村を対象とした制度であったが、平安時代に入ると平安京の中で各坊を4つの保に分割して更に各保を4町とした。
sen.e: At first the goho was the system for the agricultural community in the region, however, in the Heian period, each bo (a unit of administrative districts in Heian period) was divided into four ho (a unit of jobosei [a series of avenues running at right angles to each other marked out the system]) and, moreover, each ho composed of four cho (a unit of distance) in Heiankyo (ancient capital in current Kyoto).

sen.j: 貞観 (日本)4年（862年）には、平安京内の各保を組織して皇親・貴族の家司の中から保長を任じて、保内の治安維持に当たらせている。
sen.e: In 862, each ho within Heiankyo was organized, and a hocho was selected from keishi (household superintendent) of koshin (Emperor's family) and nobles and responsible for maintaining security of ho.
